questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding the left kidney is incorrect?

choices.text: It is the preferred side for live donor nephrectomy.
Posterior surface is related to the psoas major.
Anterior surface is related to the pancreas.
It is shorter and broader than right kidney.

questions.solution:
The left kidney is a little longer and narrower and lies nearer to the median plane than the right kidney.

The left renal vein is three times longer than right, and therefore, the left kidney is the preferred side for live donor nephrectomy. However, the left renal artery is shorter than the right renal artery.

Posterior surface of left kidney is related to the 11th and 12th ribs, diaphragm, psoas major, quadratus lumborum, subcostal nerves and vessels, ilioinguinal and iliohypogastric nerves.

Anterior surface of the left kidney is related to the suprarenal gland, stomach, spleen, pancreas, left colic flexure on the lateral side, and jejunum.

questions.text: A 62-year-old presented with diminished vision 1 year after cataract surgery. The ocular findings are shown below. The most likely diagnosis is ___________.
questions.solution:
The above image shows Elschnig’s pearls which are a type of after cataract—a delayed complication of cataract surgery.


Elschnig’s pearls are vacuolated subcapsular epithelial cells, clustered like soap bubbles, along the posterior capsule of the lens.

Types of after cataract:

  • Thin membranous after-cataract (thickened posterior capsule)
  • Dense membranous after-cataract
  • Soemmerring’s ring: peripheral thick ring of opacity between 2 capsules.
  • Elschnig’s pearls

Other options:


Option B: Irvine–Gass syndrome
Postoperative cystoid macular edema; delayed complication; clinically insignificant; resolves on its own

Option C: Delayed chronic postoperative endophthalmitis
Caused when an organism of low virulence (Propionibacterium acne or Staphylococcus epidermidis) becomes trapped within the capsular bag; characterized by pain and redness.

Option D: UGH syndrome 
Uveitis, Glaucoma, Hyphema occurring simultaneously; seen after anterior chamber intraocular lens (IOL) implantation.

questions.text: A 53 year old male patient is diagnosed with tuberculosis of the hip. On examination there is apparent lengthening of the limb. Which stage of tuberculosis of the hip presents with the above finding?
questions.solution:
In a patient with tuberculosis of the hip, apparent lengthening of the limb is seen in the stage of synovitis.

Clinical features seen in the four stages of TB hip:

  • Stage of synovitis presents with apparent lengthening of the limb due to abduction deformity. 
  • Stage of early arthritis presents with apparent shortening of the limb due to adduction deformity.
  • Stage of advanced arthritis leads to true shortening of the limb because of the destruction of the articular cartilage of the femur and the acetabulum.
  • Stage of arthritis with subluxation leads to true shortening of the limb. The destruction of acetabulum leads to dislocation of the femur head. This is also known as wandering acetabulum/ mortar and pestle hip because of the widened acetabulum and diminished size of femur head.

The TB of the hip finally results in fibrous ankylosis of the hip joint.

Note: The apparent length of the limb is measured from the umbilicus to the medial malleolus and the true length of the limb is measured from the anterior superior iliac spine to the medial malleolus. The apparent length is increased when there is abduction deformity of the limb and decreased when there is adduction deformity of the limb.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male is brought to the ER with complaints of nausea, muscle weakness and a sense of extreme fatigue. History is significant for a diagnosis of chronic kidney disease and treatment with enalapril for the same. His ECG is given below. What is the first step in management?
questions.solution:
The history points to hyperkalemia as a potential diagnosis, while absent P waves and peaked T waves on the ECG indicate cardiac toxicity of potassium. The ECG findings constitute a medical emergency and immediate intravenous infusion of calcium gluconate is the first step in management.

With cardiac monitoring, IV infusion of 10 ml of 10% calcium gluconate in 2-3 minutes reverses the cardiac depolarization blockade caused by hyperkalemia. This serves to prevent fatal arrhythmias such as sinus bradycardia/arrest, asystole, and ventricular tachycardia/fibrillation.

The next step involves the administration of intravenous regular insulin with/without iv dextrose based on monitored glucose concentrations. This serves to shift the potassium into the cells. Inhaled beta-2 agonists have an additive effect and can be used along with insulin.

IV bicarbonate is especially helpful with sustained administration over hours and if metabolic acidosis is associated with hyperkalemia.

Definitive removal of potassium from the body is accomplished using cation exchange resins, diuretics and through dialysis.

A peaked T wave is the first ECG change in hyperkalemia, and with increasing potassium concentration, P waves are lost and QRS complexes widen, ultimately deteriorating into ventricular arrhythmias/asystole.

questions.text: The likely diagnosis based on the serum electrophoresis image is:
questions.solution:
The given image demonstrates a sharp peak ("church spire” or M band) in the gamma globulin region. This is characteristically seen in a patient with multiple myeloma.

Multiple myeloma involves a malignant proliferation of plasma cells, resulting in excessive production of abnormal immunoglobulins, causing a spike called the M band.

Certain common diseases and their electrophoretic pattern:

Condition  Electrophoretic pattern
Chronic infections Smooth increase in gamma globulins
Multiple myeloma Gamma globulin part is increased (M BAND)
Liver cirrhosis Reduced albumin and compensatory increase in globulin
Primary immune deficiency Gamma globulin reduced
α1 antitrypsin deficiency α1 band is thin and even lost sometimes

questions.text: Which of the following drug interaction causes serotonin syndrome ?
questions.solution:
Serotonin syndrome is caused by the interaction between two serotonergic drugs, i.e. phenelzine (an MAO-A inhibitor) and tramadol (acts on serotonergic and noradrenergic nociception).

Serotonin syndrome can occur with any drug that increases 5-HT (eg, MAOIs, SSRIs, SNRIs, TCAs, tramadol, ondansetron, triptans, linezolid, MDMA, dextromethorphan). Co-prescription of the above-mentioned causative drugs results in increasing serotonin levels, which increase norepinephrine levels which is responsible for the autonomic symptoms in serotonin syndrome.

It is characterized by 3 A’s:

  • Neuromuscular hyperactivity- clonus, hyperreflexia, hypertonia, tremor, and seizure
  • Autonomic stimulation - hyperthermia, diaphoresis, diarrhea 
  • Agitation.

Treatment: Cyproheptadine (5-HT2 receptor antagonist). 

Although the clinical presentation of Serotonin syndrome resembles the "cheese reaction" seen in patients who take MAO-A inhibitors, the key differentiating factor is the presence of clonus. Clonus is not seen in tyramine-induced hypertensive crisis. Additionally, a hypertensive crisis is defined as systolic pressure ≥180 mmHg or diastolic ≥120 mmHg.

Cheese reaction occurs in patients being treated with MAO inhibitors who consume tyramine-rich foods. These are cheese, red wine, aged meat, and fish, etc. Apples do not cause a cheese reaction. Inhibition of the MAO-A isoform prevents the metabolism of dietary tyramine in the gut, thus allowing intact tyramine to enter the circulation. A hypertensive crisis occurs as a result of a powerful pressor effect of tyramine. This is treated with phentolamine.

questions.text: Which vector is most likely responsible for transmitting Chaga's disease?
questions.solution:
Chaga's disease is caused by Trypanosoma cruzi, transmitted by the Reduviid bug (also known as the kissing bug/ cone bug; Triatoma species). 

Chagas disease is endemic to North, Central, and South America and it is the most common parasitic cause of myocarditis and cardiomyopathy. Other parasitic causes of myocarditis and cardiomyopathy include T. brucei, Trichinella, Toxoplasma and, Toxocara canis.

Trypanosoma cruzi exists in three forms-

  • Epimastigotes- in the midgut of the reduviid bug
  • Trypomastigotes-
    • Metacyclic trypomastigotes- infective form released into the feces of the reduviid bug
    • Bloodstream trypomastigotes- extracellular infective form seen in the host bloodstream
  • Amastigotes- Intracellular replicating form. Seen predominantly in the heart muscle, parasympathetic ganglia, etc. They differentiate into trypomastigotes and are released into the bloodstream after rupture of the host cells. 

It is introduced into the host when the metacyclic trypomastigotes from the infected Reduviid bug feces are implanted into the skin due to rubbing or scratching. It can also be transmitted through blood transfusions, organ transplantation, or across the placenta. 

Following this, acute Chagas disease is seen which may be asymptomatic or be characterized by-

  • Fever
  • Regional lymphadenitis
  • Localized subcutaneous nodule at the bite site called chagoma
  • Unilateral swelling of the eyelids called the Romaña's sign. 

Some patients may progress to a chronic stage that may include-

  • Chagasic dilated cardiomyopathy with marked bilateral ventricular enlargement leading to congestive heart failure or arrhythmias and sudden death
  • Megaesophagus and megacolon. 

Diagnosis may be established by demonstrating trypomastigotes in the blood smear, PCR, serology showing antibodies or by demonstrating amastigotes in tissue biopsy. Myocardial biopsy may show a picture of myocarditis with patchy areas of infected cells and necrosis. 

Treatment of Chagas disease is most effective when administered early in the course of infection and has a lesser efficacy in chronic Chagas. Benznidazole is the drug of choice. 

Reduviid bug-

 

Other options-

Option A: Dermacentor tick is a type of hard tick responsible for transmitting Rocky Mountain spotted fever and tularemia.

 

 

Option B: Soft ticks are known to transmit relapsing fever.

 

 

Option D: Tsetse fly is responsible for transmitting Trypanosoma brucei rhodesiense and Trypanosoma brucei gambiense that cause African sleeping sickness.

questions.text: Name the sign that is being elicited here
questions.solution:
The above image illustrates Chvostek's sign.

Percussion of the facial nerve just below the zygoma causes contraction of the ipsilateral facial muscles (Chvostek' sign), seen in hypocalcemic tetany.

Another sign seen is Trousseau's sign: Carpopedal spasm is induced by occlusion of the arm with a blood pressure cuff for 3 min, raised above the systolic pressure.

High yield points:

  • Troisier sign: Enlargement of the left supraclavicular lymph node.
  • Trousseau sign in GI malignancy (Trousseau syndrome): migratory thrombophlebitis, classically described for pancreatic malignancy.

questions.text: A patient suffering from severe depression with suicidal thoughts was treated with 6 rounds of ECTs (Electroconvulsive therapy) over 3 weeks. What is the usual pattern of providing ECTs?

choices.text: 1 ECTs in the first week, 2 in second week and 3 in third week
2 ECTs in the first week, 2 in second week and 2 in third week
3 ECTs in the first week, 2 in second week and 1 in third week
4 ECTs in the first week, 1 in second week and 1 in third week

questions.solution:
When 6 ECTs are administered, the usual pattern is three ECTs in the first week, two in the second week, and one in the third week.

Severe depression with suicidality is the first and foremost indication for the use of ECT. The response is usually rapid, resulting in a marked improvement.

However, improvement is not sustained after stopping the ECTs. Therefore, antidepressants are often needed along with ECTs, in order to maintain the improvement achieved.

Related Pearl: Key points on electroconvulsive therapy

Produces grand mal seizure in an anesthetized patient.

Mechanism of action:

  • Neuroplasticity: Ability of the brain to form and reorganize synaptic connections.
  • Increases levels of Brain-Derived Growth Factor and Vascular Endothelial Growth Factor

Indications:

  • Treatment-resistant depression
  • Severe depression with suicidal risk (most common indication)
  • Depression with psychotic features
  • Depressed suicidal pregnant women
  • Refusal to eat or drink
  • Imminent risk for suicide
  • Neuroleptic malignant syndrome
  • Catatonia and catatonic schizophrenia
  • Severe agitated depression

Electrode placement: Bifrontotemporal, right unilateral.

Anesthetic agent: Methohexital (most common)

Adverse effects:

  • Retrograde amnesia (most common)
  • Partial anterograde amnesia
  • Disorientation
  • Temporary headache

Memory disturbances recover within 1-6 months. Safe in pregnancy. ECT can reverse extrapyramidal symptoms of neuroleptics.

Contraindications: No absolute contraindication (raised intracranial tension is considered as a relative contraindication).

Increased risk of adverse effects in:

  • Severe cardiovascular disease, recent myocardial infarction
  • Space occupying brain lesion
  • Recent stroke, unstable aneurysm

questions.text: Necrophilia and necrophagia are punishable under
questions.solution:
Both necrophilia and necrophagia are punishable under section 297 IPC with imprisonment upto 1 year.

  • Necrophilia: Person obtains sexual gratification by intercourse with dead bodies.
  • Necrophagia: Person sucks the wound, bites the skin, sucks the blood and eats flesh of dead body to derive sexual pleasure.

Both are punishable under section 297 IPC with imprisonment upto 1 year.

Option a: Section 290 IPC - Punishment for frotteurism with fine upto rs 2000. 

Option b: Section 294 IPC - Punishment for exhibitionism with imprisonment upto 3 months or fine. 

Option d: Section 300 IPC - Definition of murder.

questions.text: A 2-year-old boy with developmental delay and seizures was diagnosed with Lennox Gastaut syndrome. On performing an EEG, which of the following is not a typical EEG finding that you would expect to see?
questions.solution:
Hypsarrythmia is seen in West syndrome.

EEG in Lennox Gastaut syndrome shows 1-2 Hz spike and polyspike bursts in sleep with a slow background in wakefulness.

  • It typically starts between the age of 2 and 10 years
  • Consists of a triad of developmental delay, multiple seizures, and EEG findings 1-2 Hz spike and slow waves, polyspike bursts in sleep.
  • Patients will have long-term cognitive impairment and intractable seizures despite multiple therapies.
Disease Typical EEG feature
Lennox-Gastaut syndrome
  • 1-2 Hz spike and slow waves
  • polyspike bursts in sleep
  • slow background in wakefulness
Absence seizures 3 Hz spike and slow-wave (spike and dome pattern)
Juvenile myoclonic epilepsy 4-5 Hz spike
West syndrome Hypsarrhythmia (high-voltage waves with chaotic background)

questions.text: A metal factory worker suffers from noise-induced hearing loss. Which of the following structures will be affected?
questions.solution:
Noise-induced hearing loss causes damage to outer hair cells, starting in the basal turn of the cochlea. Outer hair cells are affected before the inner hair cells.

Features of NIHL:

  • Follows chronic exposure to less intense sounds
  • The audiogram in NIHL shows a typical notch, at 4 kHz, both for air and bone conduction
  • This is referred to as Acoustic Dip or Boiler’s notch
  • The noise-induced hearing loss is preventable

Properties of Sound and Noise

I) Loudness

  • Loudness or intensity depends upon the amplitude of vibrations and it is measured in decibels (dB).
  • The daily exposure of up to 85 dB is the limit that people can tolerate without substantial damage to hearing. This limit is the maximum acceptable noise limit.
Normal conversation 60 – 65 dB
Whispering 20 – 30 dB
Heavy street traffic 60 – 80 dB
Boiler factories 120 dB

 

  • Acceptable noise levels are expressed in terms of unit dBA, which is decibels conform to a weighting curve called curve A.
Area Place in area Acceptable noise levels (dBA)
Residential Bed room 25
  Living room 40
Commercial Office 35 – 45
  Conference 40 – 45
  Restaurants 40 – 60
Industrial Workshop 40 – 60
  Laboratory 40 – 50
Educational Classroom 30 – 40
  Library 35 – 40
Hospitals Wards 20 – 35

 

II) Frequency

  • It is expressed in Hertz (Hz.) and 1 Hertz is equal to one wave per second
  • The human ear can hear frequencies from about 20 to 20,000 Hz
  • Below 20 Hz. the vibrations are infra-audible and above 20,000 Hz. they are ultra-sonic

Related Pearl: Effects of Noise Exposure

  • Auditory effects
    • Auditory fatigue appears at 90 dB and is greatest at 4000 Hz. Whistling and buzzing in ear occurs with auditory fatigue.
    • Temporary deafness or hearing loss occurs after a single exposure to a noise, usually at a frequency range of 4000 – 6000 Hz. It disappears after 24 hours following noise exposure.
    • Permanent hearing loss can result after continuous or repeated exposure to noises around 100 dB. It occurs commonly as occupational hearing loss.
    • Exposure to noise above 160 dB may rupture the tympanic membrane and cause permanent hearing loss.
  • Non-auditory effects
    • Interference with speech occurs when sound has a frequency of 300 – 500 Hz
    • Annoyance is a psychological response to noise which can greatly affect efficiency and concentration
    • Noise has also been known to cause some physiological changes like increased blood pressure, intracranial pressure, increased sweating, etc.

questions.text: The contrast media used in the study depicted below is contraindicated in all of the following except:
questions.solution:
The given image is a contrast radiograph of barium meal. Barium-based contrast media can be used in case of bowel strictures but only in small amounts.  

Barium-based contrast media:

  • They are preferred for the study of the gastrointestinal tract as it is very poorly soluble and is not absorbed during its passage through the GIT
  • They can cause granulomas and, rarely, fatal reactions on leaking into the mediastinum or peritoneal cavity.
  • Therefore, they are contraindicated when:
    • (i) the integrity of the gut wall is compromised, e.g. suspected aspiration, fistula between esophagus and lungs, perforation of GIT and/or
    • (ii) there is a history of allergic reactions to barium products
  • They are used with caution in case of bowel strictures and extensive colitis
  • Complications: Leakage into the vasculature, worsening of ulcerative colitis inflammation

questions.text: Hyaluronidase participates in the degradation of _____________
questions.solution:
Hyaluronidase participates in the initial degradation of chondroitin sulphate because of its structural similarity with hyaluronic acid.

Note: Though hyaluronidase and heparan sulfate have the same major building blocks, heparan sulfate is insensitive to hyaluronidase. This is because heparan sulfate has other groups as well and the linkage is also different.
